In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves' guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.",

The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends. If you create an image of an object--such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest--it must be no larger than a 5-foot cube. Great, I'm ready to begin. Let's start by creating the characters. Each player will create a new character using the standard 5th edition "Fantasy Grounds" character sheet. Once all of the players have created their characters, we can begin the one-shot adventure.

To begin, we'll need to decide on the setting and the adventure's outcome. Let's create a simple story where the players take on the role of adventurers tasked with delivering an important package to a nearby city. As they make their way through the city, they suddenly find themselves ambushed by a group of goblins in the alleyway.

The players will each take turns rolling the dice, adding their proficiency bonus and ability modifiers as necessary to determine the outcome of their actions. For example, if a player wants to attack the goblins with their sword, they would roll a d20 + their proficiency bonus + their ability modifier, which is based on their dexterity score.

Once all of the players have had a chance to roll their dice, we'll determine the total result and modify it based on any relevant abilities or other bonuses.
